This is an excellent conversion of the board game (except the board game gives you some fighting-chance combat even after the Elder God has awakened). Learn the strategy which is to pace your characters. Let them rest at the entrance. Spend their trophies at the souvenir shop for more abilities, or spin the wheel, to have enough tricks to go for those locations rich in Elder Signs. Score big, then build again, is better than head-butting every single turn without enough abilities. Of course as the Elder Gods get harder you have less time to recover and it is a more frantic pace. Learn how to approach each Adventure. If it has steps that must be followed in order, get a lot of lock or clue cards to save glyphs or reroll them. Pay attention to the special abilities of your character too, is there one spot they can break more easily? Then build them up and come back next turn.

A highly addictive, polished adaptation of a tabletop dice game to a single-player mobile experience. Whether you like it or not will primarily depend on your frustration threshold: as other reviewers point out, this is not a game you are guaranteed to win, especially at the higher difficulties. But if you appreciate the feeling of struggling to improve your odds against a final long-shot push, and sometimes--only sometimes--having that final push succeed by a combination of luck and successful planning, this might be a game for you.  I do have a few nitpicks, not worthy of removing a star, but notable:  * Practically zero diversity in artwork. This is a game about Heroic White People (yawn). I get that Lovecraft was a bigot, but seriously, we don't need to perpetuate that nonsense in stuff based on his work. * Most luck-based elements are fair, in that the probabilities are upfront and you have many tactical and strategic methods of improving them. But a handful are not. Having a disastrous midnight effect show up _at_ midnight, and Mythos effects that remove random inventory items, are straight up BS.
If you want to pay for a game you can only win by buying in-game purchases, this is the game for you.

Whether I am spending time alone or passing my tablet around with friends or family, each one taking the role of a member of the investigative group, Elder Sign: Omens never fails to provide an entertaining and challenging good time.  Occasionally frustrating and almost never easy, some might feel the game requires more luck than skill but I would say that a good measure of both are necessary. While the outcomes of any given roll are random the ability to tune the results over the course of several rolls and even up the odds in one's own favor by using items or special abilities of various sorts adds a great deal of planning and skill to what on the surface is a mere dice game.  Production values are incredibly high with special care taken to heighten the mood of this horror-themed game with an appropriately spooky soundtrack and some stunning visuals provided by the talented artists employed by Fantasy Flight.  Fans of Lovecraftian lore should not hesitate to invest in this game as it oozes Mythos from every non-Euclidian angle. Even those gamers who are unfamiliar with the works of the gentleman from Providence should not hesitate to give this one a try.

This is almost a conversion of Arkham Horror, except that it's a conversion of the Elder Sign dice game.  The former had a lot more depth, but the latter has faster play and is more suited for a mobile conversion. But there are a number of faults that keep me from giving more than an adequate 3-star rating.    First, if you haven't played the dice game, this game is boggling for a new player.  There are tutorial videos, yes, but they make a lot of assumptions.  For example, it dives right in to explaining glyph locking, without explaining what a glyph is.    Second, it is next to impossible to predict the odds of success for any given adventure.  In the dice game, you can physically count the glyphs on the dice and make an educated guess.  It wasn't until my third game that I discovered that the red die is much more powerful than the green or yellow dice.  Third, the game lacks flavor.  The dice game has much less flavor text than Arkham Horror, but it has some and it doesn't appear in this conversion.  Fourth, the mechanics are quite opaque.  I often had no idea where doom counters came from.  Fifth, the videos were corrupted on my touchpad.  Finally, only Azathoth is implemented.
